 Houston is a slightly different situation than New Orleans. While new orleans is below seal level, houston is not. Just this single fact makes a hurricane in houston more survivable than one in New Orleans. Additionally, Houston has MUCH, MUCH stricter building codes than New Orleans. The buildings in Houston are built to withstand a category 4 storm. Flood waters in houston will drain on their own, they don't have to be pumped out. 
 
 I know a few people in houston who are not leaving. One is my uncle. He is a surgeon and feels morally compelled to stay around to help with casualties. One is an older couple that tried to get out yesterday, and after spending the entire day on the highway, they had only made it about 15 miles, and things were getting WORSE. They were at 1/4 tank of gas, and decided that weathering the storm in the city would be better than trying to weather it in their car on the highway somewhere, and that it would be better to conserve that last bit of gas than run out of gas on the highway, so they got off and went home. The third guy I know who is staying is staying to keep an eye on his business. That is kind of a unique situation in that his business, due to some of the equipment they use and hazards associated with their processes, has 10 inch thick reinforced concrete walls and a 6" concrete deck for the roof. He is trying to get their warehouse area cleaned out to use as a shelter if need be after the storm. My uncle and the old couple I mentioned earlier are going to stay with him and his family at the plant during the hurricane. I am not particularly worried about their safety (the building is designed to withstand a direct hit from a tornado with only cosmetic damage).
